header.title: Liber Juratus, or The Sworne Booke of Honorius
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Tradition, Angel Magic

central_thesis: The central thesis of the 'Liber Juratus' is to provide a comprehensive system of Christian ceremonial magic that enables the practitioner, through rigorous purification, specific prayers, and intricate ritual work involving divine and angelic names and seals, to achieve profound spiritual goals such as the vision of the Deity, knowledge of divine power, forgiveness of sins, and the redemption of souls from purgatory. Additionally, it offers practical operative magic for controlling various spirits (planetary, elemental, zodiacal, lunar mansion) to effect changes in the physical world and gain knowledge of hidden things.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the legendary origin of the book, detailing how Honorius, son of Euclid and master of Thebes, compiled it after a council of 89 masters, guided by the angel Hocroel. It emphasizes the sacredness of the text, its purpose to counter 'wicked sprites' and false magic, and includes a strict oath of secrecy and limited copying, with dire warnings against unauthorized reproduction, highlighting its exclusive and potent nature.

Outlines the first six chapters, which focus on divine knowledge: the composition of the great name of God (Schemhamphoras), the vision of the Deity, knowledge of divine power, forgiveness of sins, preventing deadly sin, and redemption of souls from Purgatory. These chapters lay the philosophical and spiritual foundation for the magical work.

Lists twenty-seven chapters concerning the knowledge and influence of celestial entities and natural phenomena: angels of every heaven, their names, powers, seals, and offices; invocation; obtaining will and sciences; knowing the hour of death; perceiving past, present, and future; understanding planets, stars, and their virtues/influences (including altering them); changing day/night; knowing spirits of air, fire, water, earth, and infernals (their names, superiors, seals, power, virtue); sight of purgatory/hell; and the consecration of the book.

Details sixty-six chapters covering practical magical operations, including the constraint of spirits by words, seals, and tables; giving spirits shape; enclosing spirits; causing weather phenomena (thunder, lightning, burning, purging/corrupting air, snow, ice, dews, rain, flowers, fruits); invisibility; acquiring horses; rapid transport/retrieval of objects; changing shapes; creating floods; causing commotions; destroying kingdoms/empires; gaining power over men; conjuring armed men/castles; creating wicked/seeing glasses; recovering stolen goods; opening locks; causing discord/unity; gaining favor; obtaining riches; healing/causing sickness or death; gathering animals (birds, fish, beasts); causing war; creating illusions (jugglers, maidens, gardens, castles, fighting men, gryphons, dragons, hunters, misdirection); and creating pleasures. Chapters 88-92 are briefly mentioned (delivering prisoners, locking gates, finding treasures, appearing dead bodies, created beasts) but two are omitted as 'against the will of God'.

This section elaborates on the philosophical underpinnings of the magic, asserting one God, one power, and one faith as the source of all perfection. It describes three kinds of angels (celestial, air, earth) and distinguishes between Jewish, Christian, and Pagan practitioners, emphasizing that true efficacy is only for Christians through belief in Christ. It also introduces the concept of the 'Seal of God' for knowledge of deity, angels, and binding dead men.

structure_content.chapter_title: -IV- Here follows the making of the Seal of the true and living God
structure_content.summary: Provides precise instructions for constructing the 'Seal of God,' a complex diagram involving multiple concentric circles, a pentagram, and heptagons. Detailed letter inscriptions (e.g., Schemhamphoras) are given for each segment, along with specific colors (red, saffron, azure, purple, black, green) for different areas. It concludes by noting the use of blood (from mole, turtledove, lapwing, bat) on virgin parchment for its creation, indicating its potent and sacred nature.

structure_content.chapter_title: -V- The beginning of the cleansing or purging of him who shall work in this art, for he must be clean from all filthiness of soul and body
structure_content.summary: This chapter outlines the essential purification rituals for the practitioner, including strict penitence, confession of sins, abstinence from women, leading a pure life, wearing clean or new apparel, and constant prayer. It emphasizes that physical and spiritual cleanliness is paramount for successful operations, linking external purity to internal virtue necessary for divine interaction.

structure_content.chapter_title: Suffumigations compounded of certain thinges here follow, attributed to the planet.
structure_content.summary: Details specific incense mixtures (suffumigations) for each day of the week and planet (Sun, Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Saturn). These compounds include various herbs, gums, and animal parts (e.g., brains, blood), designed to align with planetary influences for magical effects. It also includes suffumigations for generating visions, expelling poisons, causing illusions, and revealing hidden things.

Provides extensive lists of angelic names associated with the seven days of the week, the seven planets (including their potestates or rulers for each month), the four elements/directions (air, earth), the twelve zodiacal signs, and the twenty-eight lunar mansions. These names are crucial for invocations and binding spirits according to the grimoire's system.

Presents a series of lengthy orations (prayers), both in English and Latin, for various purposes such as consecrating the blood used for ink, general supplication to God and the Virgin Mary, seeking divine wisdom, strength, and the ability to perform the magical operations. These prayers are deeply Christian in tone, invoking the Holy Trinity, saints, and divine names to grant the practitioner's requests and aid in purification.

Provides further details on the timing and repetition of prayers based on lunar phases (4th, 8th, 12th, 15th, 18th, 21st, 23rd, 26th, 29th, 30th days of the moon), emphasizing great chastity and cleanness. It also mentions specific prayers (e.g., 'Assaylemaht' and 'O most high and invisible God') to be said multiple times at various hours of the day (morning, midday, evening) for optimal effect.

structure_content.chapter_title: -LII- ow seeing that he shall do no other thing...
structure_content.summary: Instructs the practitioner on daily routines for continuous purification and prayer (using the 6th, 10th, 12th, 14th, 21st, 24th, 29th, 30th, 32nd prayers) for twenty days, and then outlines the specific rituals to be performed on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday, including fasting, masses, and almsgiving, to ensure the success of the magical work and divine favor.

structure_content.chapter_title: -CXII- Here followeth the making of the circle
structure_content.summary: Details the construction of the magical circle, specifying hard, plain stones or tiles, joined with lime and sand from a sea bank. It requires two concentric circles of specific dimensions (14 feet diameter for outer, 7 feet inner, 3.5 feet high) and emphasizes the practitioner's cleanliness. An alternative using clean earth or clay is offered for poverty. A prayer to be recited by the priest during the consecration of the body of Christ is also included.

structure_content.chapter_title: -CIV- Of the Spirits that be under the planet Saturn (and other planets)
structure_content.summary: Describes the nature, appearance, regions, and seals of angels and their subordinate demons (kings and ministers) associated with each of the seven planets (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, Venus, Mercury, Moon). For example, Saturnine spirits cause sadness and are long, pale, and yellow, residing in the North. Each planetary section provides lists of angelic and demonic names (e.g., Bohel, Casziel for Saturn; Formione, Guth for Jupiter; Iammax, Carmox for Mars; Batthan, Thaadas for Sun; Sarabocres, Nassar for Venus; Habaa, Hyyci for Mercury; Harthan, Bileth for Moon), along with specific seals and descriptions of their powers (e.g., causing war, love, knowledge).

structure_content.chapter_title: -CXVII) End of the chapters, and beginning of the preface on the aerial spirits.
structure_content.summary: This section transitions from the vision of the Deity and angelic orders to the nature and office of the 'second angels,' specifically the spirits of the air. It explains that these spirits, unlike the higher angels, can be subjugated. The text then delves into the corruptible and subtle nature of air and its spirits, noting that some are good and mild (Eastern and Western) while others are evil, arrogant, and wild (Southern and Northern).

Outlines the process of adjuring and binding spirits. The practitioner invokes spirits by sacred names, commanding them to appear and obey. It describes the physical acts of striking the swords at cardinal directions with a hazel or laurel wand and showing the Seal of God to bind the spirits, ensuring their appearance in a 'beautiful and peaceful form' without harm.

key_concepts.term: Liber Juratus / Sworn Book of Honorius
key_concepts.definition: A medieval grimoire, compiled by Honorius, which contains a system of ceremonial magic aimed at achieving divine vision and controlling spirits. It is considered a foundational text in the grimoire tradition, emphasizing rigorous ritual purity and the use of sacred names and seals.

The central magical device in the system, intricately designed with concentric circles, a pentagram, and heptagons. It is inscribed with numerous divine and angelic names, specific letters, and symbols, and colored according to precise instructions. It is to be created on virgin parchment using consecrated blood as ink and is essential for both divine vision and spirit control.

The great 72-letter name of God, a Hebrew term central to Kabbalistic traditions. In Liber Juratus, it is a powerful divine name inscribed on the Seal of God and invoked in orations to assert divine authority over spirits and facilitate magical operations.

Long and complex liturgical texts, often in Latin and English, that are recited as part of the rituals. They involve fervent supplication to God, invocation of the Holy Trinity, the Virgin Mary, and numerous divine and angelic names. These are used for purification, consecration of tools, and commanding spirits, with specific prayers designated for different purposes and times.

Incense mixtures composed of various herbs, gums, and sometimes animal parts (e.g., brains, blood). These are prepared according to planetary associations and specific magical effects (e.g., for visions, protection, causing weather phenomena). They are burned in censers during rituals to create an appropriate magical atmosphere and attract or influence spirits.

A stringent set of physical and spiritual disciplines required of the practitioner. This includes penitence, confession, fasting (often bread and water), abstinence from sexual activity, wearing clean or new apparel, and continuous prayer. This purity is deemed essential for the efficacy of the magic, enabling the practitioner to safely interact with divine and angelic entities.

A sacred space constructed according to precise dimensions and materials, typically stones or tiles, lime, and sand. It consists of multiple concentric circles and is intended to protect the magician, serve as a focal point for operations, and contain invoked spirits. Inscriptions within and around the circle include divine and angelic names.

Angels and their subordinate demons associated with the seven classical planets (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, Venus, Mercury, Moon), the four elements, the cardinal directions, the twelve zodiacal signs, and the twenty-eight lunar mansions. Each category of spirit has distinct natures, powers, appearances, and regions of influence, which the magician aims to understand and control.

The ultimate theurgic goal of the Liber Juratus, referring to the practitioner's ability to 'see God face-to-face' while still alive. This profound spiritual experience is sought through the most intense and purified forms of ritual work, emphasizing the Christian mystical aspect of the grimoire.

A crucial magical substance, consecrated through specific orations, and used as ink for inscribing the Seal of God on virgin parchment. The type of blood is specified (e.g., mole, turtledove, lapwing, bat), indicating its vital and potent role in imbuing the magical tools with efficacy.

practical_system.description: The practical system of 'Liber Juratus' is a highly structured Christian ceremonial magic aimed at both spiritual attainment (divine vision, purification) and operative control over various classes of spirits. It centers on the practitioner's rigorous ritual purity, achieved through confession, fasting, abstinence, and devotional prayers. The core magical apparatus involves the intricate 'Seal of God' and a precisely constructed magical circle. Operations are timed according to lunar phases and days of the week, with specific orations and suffumigations tailored to the planetary, elemental, zodiacal, and lunar mansion spirits being invoked. The system emphasizes divine authority, utilizing potent divine and angelic names (including the Schemhamphoras) to command spirits for obtaining knowledge, physical effects, and spiritual benefits.
tools: Seal of God (Sigillum Dei Aemeth): A complex diagram inscribed with divine and angelic names, colored with specific pigments, and created using consecrated blood as ink.
Magical Circle: Constructed from stones or tiles, lime, and sand, with specific dimensions and internal diagrams for protection and operation.
Wand/Baculus: A staff made of laurel or hazel wood, consecrated and used to strike the swords in the circle and direct spiritual energy.
Censer: Used for burning suffumigations during rituals.
Incense/Suffumigations: Specific mixtures of herbs, gums, and sometimes animal parts, prepared according to astrological and magical properties.
Holy Water: Used for purification, likely consecrated using exorcised salt.
Consecrated Blood: Derived from specific animals (mole, turtledove, lapwing, bat) and blessed for use as ink for the Seal of God.
Clean Apparel: New or thoroughly cleaned garments to be worn by the practitioner, symbolizing ritual purity.
New Knife: Used for specific ritual markings and preparations.
Swords: Placed at the cardinal directions of the magical circle, to be struck with the wand during invocations.
rituals: Rigorous purification: This involves detailed confession, penance, fasting (often bread and water), abstinence from women, wearing clean or new apparel, and a consistently pure life. Prayers for purity and divine grace are said daily.

Consecration of the Seal of God: Involves drawing a complex diagram with concentric circles, a pentagram, and heptagons. Specific divine and angelic names, letters, and symbols are inscribed onto the seal, which is then colored according to precise instructions, often using consecrated blood as ink.

Construction of the Magical Circle: Requires a precisely measured and constructed circle of stones or tiles, lime, and sand, with specific dimensions and internal diagrams, to serve as a sacred and protective workspace for the operation.

Timing of Operations: Rituals are aligned with specific lunar phases (e.g., 4th, 8th, 12th, 15th, 18th, 21st, 23rd, 26th, 29th, 30th days of the moon) and days of the week (e.g., Friday, Saturday, Sunday, Monday for specific planetary spirits).

Daily Prayer Cycles: Specific orations (e.g., the 100 Holy Names of God, Marian prayers, planetary invocations) are to be recited multiple times a day (morning, midday, evening) over extended periods (e.g., 20 days) to accumulate spiritual power and achieve the desired effect.

Suffumigations: Incense mixtures are prepared according to planetary correspondences, elements, and specific magical intentions (e.g., for visions, healing, causing discord). These are burned in a censer during the operation.

Invocation and Adjuration of Spirits: Involves reciting lengthy orations filled with divine and angelic names to call forth and command specific planetary, elemental, zodiacal, or lunar mansion spirits. The practitioner uses a consecrated wand to strike the swords placed at the cardinal directions of the circle and displays the Seal of God to bind the spirits.
Dialogue with Spirits: Once invoked and bound, spirits are expected to appear in a 'beautiful and peaceful form' and answer questions or fulfill commands without harm, under divine authority.

Spiritual Goals: Rituals can aim for divine vision, knowledge of divine power, forgiveness of sins, preventing deadly sin, and redeeming souls from purgatory, demonstrating a theurgic and soteriological dimension.

critical_analysis.relevance: The 'Liber Juratus' is a profoundly relevant text within Western Esotericism, considered one of the oldest and most influential grimoires of Medieval magic. It offers a unique synthesis of Christian piety and operative magic, seeking not only the control of spirits for worldly ends but also the ultimate theurgic goal of divine vision and spiritual purification. Its intricate ritual structures, extensive lists of divine and angelic names (including the Schemhamphoras), and detailed instructions for constructing magical tools like the Seal of God, served as a foundational source and point of reference for later grimoires and influential occultists like Agrippa and the Heptameron tradition. The explicit connection between Christian doctrine and practical magic is a key distinguishing feature, contrasting with more purely 'demonic' grimoires. It provides invaluable insight into the historical development of ceremonial magic and the complex relationship between religious belief and magical practice in the medieval period.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this work is primarily practitioners of ceremonial magic, particularly those interested in the historical grimoire tradition and Christian-oriented theurgy. It also caters to academic scholars of Western Esotericism, occultism, and the history of religions, who seek to understand the philosophical and practical mechanics of medieval magic. The stringent requirements for ritual purity, fasting, and dedicated prayer imply an audience committed to an ascetic or monastic lifestyle, or at least capable of intense self-discipline, rather than a casual enquirer. The highly detailed and complex instructions necessitate a serious and patient practitioner with a strong spiritual inclination.
